name: Kepler-174
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-174 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-174 is a star with 0.5199999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.62 times its radius. It is located 1268.98 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-174 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-174 b

Kepler-174 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.98 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-174.

The mass of Kepler-174 b is 4.85 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-174 b is 1.96 that of Earth. At 4.85 Earth masses, Kepler-174 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-174 c

Kepler-174 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 44.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-174.

The mass of Kepler-174 c is 2.51 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-174 c is 1.49 that of Earth. At 2.51 Earth masses, Kepler-174 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.214 astronomical units, and a mass of 2.51 Earth masses, Kepler-174 c could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.

Kepler-174 d

Kepler-174 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.68 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 247.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-174.

The mass of Kepler-174 d is 6.28 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-174 d is 2.19 that of Earth. At 6.28 Earth masses, Kepler-174 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-174, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
